Edit:

Before you do set up, you'll want to work on your ships.

The reason the destroyers fell apart is because they were made out of armour plates. Zeke's ships, for example, use a central spine with branches. The armour is stuck to the branches, creating an open space inside between the tough metal spine and the armour for things like fuel tanks and torpedoes.

When a missile strikes the plates of your current design, the plates will break. Any good missile will break an armour plate or two. But if a missile strikes the armour on a design that has a metal spine inside, the armour will break, but the spine will remain intact. This will keep the ship from breaking in half.

Your ships each had only one shot. A ship is considered "dead" if it has either no engines, no electricity, or no weapons (though if there are some lying around, you can go get them). Both of your other fighters were considered "dead" as soon as they took their shots.

Because this game is turn based, you'll want to find ways to stay a turn ahead of your opponent. If you have ordnance left over after your turn, that ship will get another turn later, or be another target your opponent will be forced to waste ammo on on their turn. Try to bring as many shots as is reasonable for the weight limit.

Since guided weapons are forbidden, you can cut down on tonnage and parts by eliminating them from your ship. Use lighter, faster, dumb-fire missiles, or heavier bulky dumb-fire torpedoes (Macey's Hades torpedo, for example). Be sure the warhead (the part on the front) is something with a high impact rating as high as the armor plating's impact rating (80).
